DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Kill 11 in Andean Highlands of Peru
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas killed 11 people, including a judge and a teacher, in three separate attacks in the Peruvian highlands, police said Sunday. The bodies of a married couple and another man, all peasant farmers, were found Sunday in the ashes of a house destroyed by fire in the town of Chaquicocha, 30 miles west of Huancayo. The city in the Andean highlands 140 miles east of Lima is a hub of guerrilla activity. Police said a message painted on a wall of the burned house said: ``Death to informers.'' The victims' bodies showed bullet wounds in the head and signs of torture. Police also said Shining Path guerrillas shot to death seven people in two neighboring villages 27 miles south of Huancayo on Friday, including a judge and a teacher from the village of Moya. The other five victims were from San Mateo. Another peasant farmer was shot to death late Saturday in his home in Sapallanga, a village six miles southeast of Huancayo, according to police. The Mao-inspired Shining Path launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 17,000 people have died in the violence.
